fields.description:
I created a policy and manually changed "allow" to another word that is not valid policy statement syntax. I then clicked the submit button and got an error back from the CLC and my policy was gone bye bye. I lost all my work, sad face. 

Can we check the validity of policies while the gen tool is still open (probably on send prior to sending) so that we can let users know their policy is no bueno and they can fix it right then, without having to start over from scratch, please.
fields.summary: user's work is lost if they create a policy with an invalid statement

comments.body: [~jloza]: The best we can do here is to display if the JSON is valid or not.  That won't catch the use case you mentioned, however, and there isn't much we can do to validate each statement without a significant amount of work.

[~kgill] I think we already do validate the json...hm, we should think about this at the summit and see if we can come up with something perhaps for 4.0.1 that might makes sense from an implementation perspective that would help.

[~jloza]: We aren't validating the JSON in real-time, since the JSON generated from the policy generator tool is valid JSON.  To handle the case where the policy textarea is manually edited, we could display a warning if invalid JSON has been entered.
[~kgill] I'll add this to the summit agenda so we can discuss as a team. Thanks!

We can only check JSON syntax, which we do. If the CLC deletes the policy when an update is invalid, that's a back-end problem. I sincerely hope AWS doesn't do that!
The docs for PutUserPolicy simply says this;
MalformedPolicyDocument
The request was rejected because the policy document was malformed. The error message describes the specific error.

HTTP Status Code: 400

I don't find that conclusive, so I'll keep looking.

I just did a test with the aws cli tools. I was able to set a policy for an IAM user. I was able to change the policy with "aws iam put-user-policy...". Then, I tried using a policy that had some invalid words and that failed. I then verified with the aws console that the previous good policy was in place for that user. So, it looks like PutUserPolicy with an invalid policy is non-destructive.

Plus, aws replied a forum post of mine: https://forums.aws.amazon.com/thread.jspa?messageID=540056&#540056

I just did a test with euca2ools. I created the same policy I did for AWS. I then updated the policy with the same invalid one. I got the MalformPolicyDocument error. I was then able to retrieve the previous good policy for that user. I am concluding that we are doing something poorly in the console. I'll investigate.

[~kgill] this is not 4.0 critical, but we should try and address it ASAP since it's really bad for users to lose their work. I suggest we put it on the list for possible inclusion in 4.0.1.

[~dkavanagh], Ha what I did was replace "allow" with "fart" (because we are all mature adults here) in the policy gen tool launched form a group's detail page, (I chose the middle template to get text into the policy view area on the right) and when I clicked Create Policy I got the error back from the CLC and the tool closed and the group's detail page was displayed again. The policy was not created. If I had made a custom policy with lots of statements and then lost it, it would be a huge bummer. 

I am using the team dev cloud also, just pulled fresh from develop. Mac osx 10.9.2, FF 28.0

Ah right. Now I understand better. You had a lot of un-saved work. Gotcha. We'd have to handle this as an AJAX call so we don't leave the page while saving. That would fix it, but not sure that level of work is suitable this late in the game. We should discuss.
I am OK with pushing this to 4.0.1 if this is at all a non-trivial amount of work.
Just to clarify, it isn't non-trivial, but probably more lines of code would change than we'd want at this point. I agree that it is enough of a corner case that we could handle in 4.0.1 or 4.1
OK, thanks y'all! Confirmed and put in the 4.0.1 backlog.
https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/751
Pull request 751 merged.  Assigning to [~jloza] for UX review

I removed a curly brace and got an invalid message, can we reword this so that it more accurately describes the problem? I have no idea what this means. 

Also, if we could at least show a line number in the file where the issue is that would make this exponentially more helpful. 

Also, I replaced the curly brace and comma I had originally removed and the validation error does not clear and I can't click submit, then it would let me submit but did not create the policy. I got a blank red error box like a CLC error that disappeared right away. .

I got "SyntaxError: JSON.parse: expected ',' or ']' after array element at line 5 column 15 of the JSON data" when removing a curly brace. I replaced the curly brace and the error went away and the policy was submitted normally (FF). Will test in chrome.

I will say that the error reporting is just what JSON.parse gives me. Have no control over that, it's just a helpful tool for client validation.
oh, boy. Chrome's version of JSON.parse gives horrible messages "SyntaxError: Unexpected token ]" for the same missing {

We rely on the native JSON parsing for error messages. JQuery and some other libraries also rely on the native parsing (in the browser). I think this is something we'll have to live with for 4.0.1 and possibly address in 4.1 if want to pull in some other JSON validation library in pure javascript. I've looked and am not sure if there's an obvious choice right now.
